data.title: Microsoft: Q3 Shows Azure On Cloud Nine, But Sadly So Is The Valuation
data.description:
Investment Thesis

The last time I wrote about Microsoft (MSFT), in July 2025, I analysed the company’s Q4 results and explored the key takeaways from the quarter, with a special focus on whether the company’s AI investments were paying off. I had a HOLD rating on the name.

Since the article was published, the stock hit my then price target of $542 before tumbling, registering an overall decline of 1.30%, compared with a gain of 8.21% for the S&P 500 during the same period.

MSFT announced its Q1 results yesterday and despite a strong quarter, the stock still slipped. In this article, I analyse the Q1 numbers and the overall report in detail to identify what factors could have led to the post-earnings selloff. Moreover, MSFT went into the earnings release with the stock near all-time highs. Therefore, I also analyse the company’s valuation using a quantitative model to see if it was a factor behind the selloff.

A Snapshot of Q1 Earnings Report

MSFT started the new fiscal year strongly, comfortably beating both the top- and bottom-line estimates. More specifically, Q1 revenues came in at $77.67 billion, up 17% y/y on a constant currency basis and beating analyst estimates by $2.28 billion. Diluted EPS came in at $4.13, up 21% y/y on a constant currency basis, and comfortably beating analyst estimates by $0.47. Operating margins were strong, coming in at 49%, which translates to an expansion of 200 bps (or 2%) y/y and an expansion of 410 bps (or 4.1%) sequentially.

The guidance from the company was also strong, with Q2 revenues expected to be in the range between $79.5 billion and $80.6 billion and operating margins expected to be flat on a y/y basis and down sequentially, “aligned with historic seasonality.” Capital expenditures, a metric that investors keenly watch out for, when it comes to companies such as MSFT, are now projected to not only grow sequentially but also are expected to have a higher growth rate in FY26 relative to FY25.

Azure’s Strength & Massive Bookings Jump Justifies Further Capex Spend

MSFT’s stock, at the time of writing, is down 2.2%, and it is hard for me to identify the precise catalyst behind the sell-off. It could be that the stock was at an all-time high going into the earnings, or it could be because of the increasing capex spending that the company announced at the time of reporting Q2 results.

If it’s the latter that’s driving the sell-off, then the reaction, in my view, is certainly overdone. This is because if one looks at the overall performance of the company as well as the underlying demand that continues to outpace supply, then I don’t see any option in front of the company other than to spend more.

Take Azure, for instance. The segment came into the quarter with a lot of momentum and has exited the quarter with even more momentum, as it delivered a 40% y/y growth. And while on a sequential basis, the growth has only marginally ticked up from 39%, this time last year, Azure’s revenue growth stood at 33%.

Moreover, the demand for Azure continues to remain strong, as evidenced by a massive jump in the commercial bookings, which increased 111% in constant currency in Q1. The growth does not account for the additional $250 billion Azure commitments from OpenAI that was announced as part of the ChatGPT-parent’s restructuring plans, which suggests that the growth is likely to continue. Furthermore, as further evidence of how substantial the demand for Azure is, MSFT announced that its commercial remaining performance obligations reached $392 billion, which translates to a growth of 51% y/y.

As evidenced by the above chart, this is the highest RPO growth in the last five quarters and given that the growth stood at 21% this time last year, it reflects the significant contribution that AI has played both with respect to Azure and with respect to Microsoft 365. What is even more impressive, to me, is that the weighted average duration has remained stable, despite the huge growth, at 2 years. It was also notable that management, during the earnings call, mentioned that there was sufficient breadth in the demand (numerous products, customers of all sizes) since this mitigates some of the concentration risk that the company has, with OpenAI as one of its largest customers.

Given the rapid growth seen in bookings and given that the company is generating a substantial ROI on its capex, I don’t see any reason for the company to not spend more on capital expenditures and mitigate the capacity constraints. The company has been spending while maintaining strong margins and strong growth, and with such high demand, I don’t think this time’s going to be any different. This is primarily why I believe that the negative stock reaction, post earnings release, is overdone if capex spend is the catalyst.

This is not to say that it was a perfect quarter from MSFT. For instance, MSFT reported a $3.1 billion loss this quarter compared to a $523 million loss during the same period last year. This is a substantial amount, and when asked about it during the earnings call, CFO Amy Hood confirmed that it was indeed the case, which is a substantial figure in my opinion. Ms. Hood also highlighted in her prepared remarks that going forward, outlook for other income and expense will exclude “any impact from our investments in OpenAI,” due to the “ongoing nature of our partnership resulting in increased volatility.” This is not exactly reassuring to investors, at least in near-to-medium term, especially with MSFT boosting their capex spending. This could be one of the reasons why the stock is down post-earnings.

Furthermore, Azure’s growth in Q2 is projected to slide down to 37% due to capacity constraints, which could have also triggered a knee-jerk reaction. Finally, while the company’s search business has shown accelerated growth in recent quarters, the growth rate may be stalling, or even declining, as shown below. While search is a small part of the company’s business, MSFT’s AI moves were expected to keep the segment’s growth momentum going.

Overall, it was a strong quarter from MSFT. The announcement of an increase in capex spending in FY26 seems to have not gone down well with the market. However, given that the company’s core segments that rely on these investments are generating substantial growth, and with demand continuing to outpace supply, I don’t see a reason why the company should slow down its spending. Moreover, it has the cash to spend as well as return excess capital to shareholders, so I don’t see a problem in this move by MSFT.

Valuation

Forward P/E Multiple Approach

Price Target

$558.00

Projected Forward P/E Multiple

34.85x

Projected EPS in the next twelve months

$16.01

Sources: Seeking Alpha and Author’s Chosen Model (MS-ARIMA)

I deployed a Markov-Switching Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (MS-ARIMA) model to forecast MSFT’s EPS for the rest of FY26. MS-ARIMA is a regime-switching time-series model that addresses structural breaks, unlike traditional ARIMA models. MSFT is a company that has regularly gone through regime changes, with the AI revolution being the latest switch and therefore, MS-ARIMA is an appropriate model to predict MSFT’s future EPS. More information on the model can be found here.

Data on MSFT’s EPS was obtained from Financial Modelling Prep. EPS for the last twelve quarters were selected to ensure that there was a fine balance between recency and stability. Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regressions were then deployed on the 12-quarter window. The model was validated through out-of-sample testing on the last three quarters. The out-of-sample testing resulted in the following model metrics:

Metric

MS-ARIMA

Notes

Mean Absolute Error (MAE)

0.252

Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE)

0.286

Values close to MAE suggest that there are no extreme outliers in both models.

Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE)

6.68%

MAPE values under 10% shows that the model is very good for forecasting. The directional accuracy of the model is 100%, which supports the model accuracy.

Other forecasting models such as Prophet and Random Forests were also deployed, but the MS-ARIMA had the lowest errors compared to these models, which further validated its selection.

The MS-ARIMA model was then used to forecast the EPS of the next three quarters of FY26, and the results are shown below:

Quarter-End

Projected EPS

Q2 FY26

$3.84

Q3 FY26

$3.96

Q4 FY26

$4.08

The total EPS for FY26 would be $16.01. According to Seeking Alpha, MSFT currently trades at a forward P/E 34.85x. At this multiple and with a projected FY26 of $16.01, my price target for MSFT is $558, which represents about 6% upside from current levels. The limited upside is unsurprising, given that the stock was trading at all-time highs prior to earnings.

From a momentum perspective, MSFT’s momentum has weakened in the last three months, as evidenced by the C+ grade on Seeking Alpha’s momentum scale.

Taking these together, the current levels are not attractive to initiate a position based on my analysis. As such, I am maintaining my HOLD rating. Having said that, any major pullback in the name warrants a buying opportunity in my view. Finally, I don’t see any reason for existing investors to exit their positions at current levels given the strong tailwinds that the company has.

Concluding Thoughts

MSFT had a strong start to the year, with a beat on both the top- and bottom-lines. The company further justified its massive capex spending, as evidenced by the strong growth seen in Azure as well as the exponential growth seen in its commercial bookings. Operating margins were also very strong.

Post the earnings release, despite delivering a strong quarter, the stock fell, which I believe could be either due to the significant jump in OpenAI-related losses, or the projected deceleration in Azure in Q2 due to capacity constraints. An alternative to these two causes would be valuation, which my analysis suggests is the case. MSFT went into the earnings near all-time highs, so any negative news was bound to get punished. While my rating on the stock is HOLD, it’s on a pure valuation basis and not due to the fundamentals of the business. Any major pullback would be a buying opportunity in my view. Given the negative sentiment I am currently seeing in the market because of the irrational fear for capex spending, I believe such opportunities should be around the corner.

data.title: Eurozone Inflation Drops Back To 2.1% As Services Inflation Ticks Up
data.description:
By Bert Colijn, Chief Economist, Netherlands

Thanks to easing energy base effects – what a snooze, I know – headline inflation in the eurozone has ticked back down from 2.2 to 2.1% again. The European Central Bank calls this ‘the good place’ that it's currently in, illustrating that boring times are the best times for central bankers. It made yesterday’s decision to hold rates quite straightforward, and today’s numbers emphasise that this was probably the right call. Eurozone inflation has moved within 0.2ppt of the 2% target since March, and we don’t expect it to deviate much for the foreseeable future.

Still, at the ECB press conference yesterday, President Christine Lagarde emphasised the concern around services inflation being persistently too high to balance out downside risks to inflation. Today’s data actually showed a further acceleration in services inflation, from 3.2 to 3.4%. The focus has been a bit more on downside risks to the inflation outlook in recent weeks, which could well push the inflation outlook lower. Today’s data stresses that the risks to the outlook do remain quite balanced, though, and resulted in a still-elevated core inflation rate at 2.4%.

Inflation is measured on a year-on-year basis, but the shorter-term developments do show a slight pickup of momentum in core inflation on the back of services prices. The three-month rate of core inflation is currently increasing to an annualised 2.7% rate. Then again, selling price expectations for services have eased further, which is a decent predictor of future price developments. For the months ahead, we do expect a further easing of the inflation rate, but not much below the 2% mark. The 'good place' seems to be with us for some time to come.

Content Disclaimer

This publication has been prepared by ING solely for information purposes irrespective of a particular user's means, financial situation or investment objectives. The information does not constitute investment recommendation, and nor is it investment, legal or tax advice or an offer or solicitation to purchase or sell any financial instrument. Read more

data.title: Vanadium Miners News For The Month Of October 2025
data.description:
Welcome to the Vanadium miners news.

October saw China spot vanadium pentoxide prices flat (Europe was lower) and ferrovanadium prices flat for the past month.

Vanadium uses

Vanadium is traditionally used to harden steel. Chinese rebar standards are requiring more vanadium. Also Vanadium Flow Batteries [VRFBs] are becoming increasingly popular especially for commercial energy storage, most notably in China. Vanadium Pentoxide [V2O5] is used in VRFBs and Ferrovanadium [FeV] is used in the steel industry.

Vanadium spot price history

China V2O5 prices were flat the last month. The Shanghai Metal market price on October 29 was US$9,077/t (VAT excluded). Europe V205 prices fell.

Europe & China Vanadium Pentoxide [V2O5] Flake 98% one year price chart (as of Oct. 21, 2025) - Europe = USD 4.19/lb, China = USD 4.16/kg

As of October 28, 2025, Argus Media reports the China Ferro-vanadium (80%V) FOB price at US$23.40/kg, flat for the past month.

Europe and China Ferrovanadium [FeV] 80% one year price chart - Europe = USD 23.40/kg, China = USD 23.60/kg (as of Oct. 20-21, 2025)

Vanadium demand versus supply

An April 2021 Wood Mackenzie report stated:

Global energy storage deployment surged a remarkable 62% in 2020, with 5 GW/9 GWh of new capacity added. This brought the total energy storage market to more than 27 GWh. Furthermore, we expect the global (energy storage) market to grow 27-fold by 2030.

ResearchAndMarkets forecasts the global VRFB market to grow from US$298m in 2023 to US$921m in 2028, at a CAGR of 20.5% (as of January 2023) (source)

Global VRFB forecast growth by region 2022-2031

Large scale global deployments of VRFBs are becoming more common - chart sourced as of April 2025 (source)

VRFB installations are rapidly appearing globally, notably in China (source)

Vanadium (8.5x) & Lithium (10x) demand forecast to surge the most under the IEA Net Zero Emission scenario (source)

Vanadium market news

On October 10 Vanitec reported: "Yunnan’s Yongren 100MW/400MWh Vanadium Flow Battery Project achieves 220 kV substation grid-connection."

On October 20 CNBC reported: "U.S. and Australia sign critical minerals agreement with $8.5 billion project pipeline." The focus was on rare earths.

On October 21 ABC News reported:

Donald Trump says critical minerals deal with Australia will produce 'so much' in race against China...The US-AU Critical Minerals Framework is expected to begin investing in about a dozen projects necessary for producing weapons, electronics and renewables...Altogether the Australian and US governments intend to spend $US3 billion ($4.6 billion) in the next six months to make "immediate" investments in a pipeline of critical minerals projects in nearly every state and territory in Australia... [it] isn't just digging things up, it's also about processing...In exchange for the financing, the Australian and US governments will be able to take a stake in the ownership of those facilities, and be granted a "right of offtake", essentially guaranteeing some of the supply from those facilities will be available to Australia and the US...A separate critical minerals "strategic reserve" could remove some risk for investors by setting a floor price on "priority" minerals. It is not due to come into effect until the end of next year. A government task force is considering potential price support mechanisms and what minerals will be supported.

On October 27 Directors Talk Interviews reported:

Why vanadium is starting to matter in new places. Steel has always been the centre of gravity for vanadium. But for the first time, that balance is beginning to shift...As long-duration battery technology gains ground, vanadium is increasingly being pulled into the energy transition, particularly through vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs), which use the metal as their key electrolyte. VRFBs are not new, but they are now entering a more serious growth phase. Installed capacity is expected to rise ten-fold by 2030, moving from 4 GWh today to around 40 GWh, with potential annual deployments of up to 50 GWh. As this happens, the amount of vanadium directed to battery storage could climb from around 5% of total supply to nearly 27% over the next five years.

Note: Bold emphasis by the author.

Vanadium miner news

Vanadium producers

Glencore [LSX:GLEN] [HK:805] (OTCPK:GLCNF)

Glencore is a large vanadium producer, but vanadium production represents only a small portion of their revenue.

On October 17 Mining Weekly reported:

Community unrest erupts at Glencore’s Rhovan mine after expiry of solar project contracts...Rhovan, a vanadium mining and processing facility managed by Glencore Ferroalloys, began construction of the solar plant in 2024 as part of its efforts to support sustainable energy use...Now, after being notified that their contracts will not be renewed, the affected employees have expressed dissatisfaction and initiated a labour dispute, demanding continued employment. In protest, they have blocked access roads to the mine and are calling for operations to be halted...The company said the decision to end the contracts was made in line with the terms agreed upon at the start of the project.

On October 29 Glencore announced: "Third Quarter 2025 Production Report." No vanadium details were given.

AMG Critical Materials N.V. [NA:AMG] [GR:ADG] (OTCPK:AMVMF) ("AMG")

AMG Vanadium is a leading provider of products and services for the metals, manufacturing, refinery and petrochemical industries. You can read more about AMG Vanadium here.

No vanadium related news for the month.

Largo Inc. [TSX:LGO] [GR:LR81] (LGORF)(NASDAQ:LGO)

Largo Inc. is a pure-play vanadium pentoxide producer from their Maracás Menchen Mine in Brazil as well as a producer of VRFBs.

On October 1 Largo announced:

Largo receives executed Binding Term Sheet from lenders representing US$84.2 million of debt to defer principal payments subject to certain conditions...subject to Largo securing capital of at least C$30 million by November 17, 2025..."With a deferral of principal payments, Largo would have a longer runway to restructure its bank debt.”

On October 22 Largo announced: "Closing of US$23.4M Registered Direct Offering and Private Placement."

Energy Fuels Inc. [TSX:EFR] (UUUU)

Energy Fuels state they are "the No. 1 uranium producer in the U.S. with a market-leading portfolio", as well as being a small vanadium producer.

On October 3 Energy Fuels announced:

Energy Fuels announces closing of upsized US$700.0 Million Convertible Senior Notes offering and full exercise of initial purchasers' option to purchase additional notes...We believe the convertible notes, with an attractive annual coupon of 0.75%, compare favorably to traditional debt financing...This strategic capital raise strengthens our balance sheet and enhances our ability to accelerate our rare earth initiatives, including the expansion at our White Mesa Mill and Donald Project in Australia.

Ferro-Alloy Resources [LON:FAR]

FAR is operating the giant Balasausqandiq vanadium project in Kyzylordinskaya Oblast of southern Kazakhstan. FAR stated in May 2025: "On a forward looking basis, process plant operations will be conducted only when suitably profitable raw materials are available."

On September 30 Ferro-Alloy Resources announced:

Interim results for the six months ended 30 June 2025 and feasibility study update. As previously announced, the main purpose of the existing process plant was changed to a research and development facility, with concentrates only being treated when profitable to do so. The research and development has been targeted at areas that will assist in the development of the Project and marketing its products...Total revenues of US$2.5 million for the period (H1 2024: US$2.1 million) reflected the processing of concentrates with a higher molybdenum content than in the prior year, benefiting from the currently high molybdenum prices. Overall loss for the period was US$3.5 million (H1 2024: loss of US$3.99 million). Cash balance of US$0.4 million at the period end and US$0.5 million as at 23 September 2025.

On October 13 Ferro-Alloy Resources announced:

Positive Feasibility Study results...on Phase 1 of the large Balasausqandiq vanadium deposit (the "Project") in Southern Kazakhstan.

Highlights

  • Compelling economics with net present value ("NPV") of US$748m (post tax discount rate of 8%) and Project internal rate of return ("IRR") of 22%.
  • Funding required to enter production of US$520m.
  • Bottom decile of industry cash operating costs, with attractive by-product credit value upside: Cash cost of US$4.35 per pound ("lb"). Cash cost of US$0.36/lb (net of by-product credits).
  • Vanadium pentoxide annual production of 8,500 tonnes.
  • Mine life of 20 years.
  • Phase 2 expansion could increase total production to four times the Phase 1 level, based on ore-bodies 2, 3 and 4, ("OB2,3,4") with an equally long mine life.
  • Areas for optimisation show the potential to significantly improve NPV and IRR following the completion of front-end engineering design ("FEED").
  • Discussions ongoing with potential customers for a new type of CBS (announced on 27 June 2025) to be made from the mine waste, additional to the current CBS.
  • Discussions in progress, with expressions of interest received from potential debt and equity providers.

Western Uranium & Vanadium Corp. (OTCQX:WSTRF)

Western Uranium & Vanadium Corp. own the Sunday Mine Complex which is an advanced stage mine property consisting of five interconnected underground mines in Colorado, USA.

On October 14 Western Uranium & Vanadium Corp. announced:

Closing of Mineral Lode claims acquisition...The Claims encompass a drilled-out uranium-vanadium deposit originally advanced during prior exploration programs, securing for Western a 50% ownership interest in the area covered by historic drilling. This strategic acquisition further strengthens the Company’s growing portfolio of conventional uranium and vanadium assets in the western U. S., adding to the Company’s advancing production pipeline, which includes the Sunday Mine Complex, the Sage Mine, the Van 4 Mine and the San Rafael Projects.

VanadiumCorp Resource Inc. [TSXV:VRB][GR:NWN] (OTCPK:VRBFF)

VanadiumCorp Resource Inc. 100% owns the Lac Dore Vanadium-Iron-Titanium Project in Quebec Canada. The Company is looking to take a vertically integrated approach and is also developing leading process technologies ‘VanadiumCorp-Electrochem Processing Technology’ and "Electrochem globally patented Electrowinning" technology.

On October 15 VanadiumCorp announced:

Update on strategic mining projects amid growing demand for critical minerals...an update on its 100% owned vanadium-titanium-iron (V-Ti-Fe) mineral properties in Quebec, Canada...The Company’s flagship Lac Doré and Iron-T projects provide secure, domestic sources of vanadium and titanium...Lac Doré Property – Advancing geological insight and resource definition...Iron-T Project – Expanding critical minerals portfolio...compiling and re-evaluating historical geological, geophysical, and geochemical data to guide future exploration programs.

On October 20 VanadiumCorp announced: "VanadiumCorp provides overview of Lac Laura Gold Property."

Vanadium developers

Vanadium Resources Limited [ASX:VR8] [GR:TR3]

Vanadium Resources is a junior exploration company established with the purpose of exploring and developing gold zinc, lead, copper and other mineral opportunities. Vanadium Resources owns 86.49% of a globally significant vanadium project, the Steelpoortdrift [SPD] Project, in Gauteng Province, South Africa.

On October 1 Vanadium Resources announced:

New CEO appointment to drive towards near-term production. Appointment of experienced South African mining entrepreneur Mr. Nick Diack as Chief Executive Officer with immediate effect...an extensive track record across the Bushveld Complex, and most recently raising over ZAR 800 million and leading the acquisition of Vanchem.

Australian Vanadium [ASX:AVL] [GR:JT71]

Australian Vanadium is an emerging vanadium producer focused on their Australian Vanadium Project in Western Australia. VSUN Energy was launched by AVL in 2016 to target the energy storage market for vanadium redox flow batteries [VRFBs].

On September 30 Australian Vanadium announced:

Annual Report to shareholders...AVL is one of the few companies globally with capability across the full vanadium supply chain – from resource extraction to electrolyte manufacture to integrated storage solutions. This makes AVL a compelling and differentiated investment proposition.

On October 8 Australian Vanadium announced: "$4.9 million received from Federal Grant."

On October 21 Australian Vanadium announced: "Proposed share consolidation. Share consolidation of 25:1 is proposed for shareholder approval."

On October 22 Australian Vanadium announced:

Receipt of loan funds...it has received US$10 million (less the establishment fee and lender legal costs which together total US$0.5 million) pursuant to the loan facility with its major shareholder RCF Private Equity Fund I L.P...

Richmond Vanadium Technology [ASX:RVT] ("RVT")

RVT now owns 100% of the Richmond Vanadium Project. It has a global Mineral Resource of 1.8Bt @ 0.36% Vanadium Pentoxide (V2O5).

On October 27 RVT announced:

Quarterly Activities Report for the Period Ending 30th September 2025...the focus remained on delivering tangible outcomes within the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS), advancing project definition activities and deepening strategic partnerships critical to the Project’s long-term success.

Phenom Resources Corp. [TSXV:PHNM] (OTCQX:PHNMF) (formerly First Vanadium Corp.)

The Carlin Gold-Vanadium Property hosts one of North America’s largest richest primary vanadium deposits, located in Nevada. Its West Jerome project targets a large scale high grade copper and zinc deposit in Arizona. Carlin has a Historic Inferred Resource 28Mt at 0.525% V2O5 (2010 SRK).

On October 3 Phenom Resources announced: "Phenom closes $704,000 Private Placement financing with strategic investors."

CleanTech Vanadium Mining Corp. [TSXV:CTV] (OTCQB:CTVFF)

CleanTech Vanadium's flagship project is the Gibellini Vanadium Project in Nevada, USA. Gibellini holds 127 million pounds of measured and indicated V2O5, with 195 million pounds inferred. CleanTech aims to start the first North American vanadium mine. The Gibellini Vanadium Project has also shown potential for gold exploration.

No news for the month.

QEM Limited [ASX:QEM]

QEM Limited owns the Julia Creek Vanadium and Energy Project ("JCVEP") in North Western Queensland, Australia.

On September 30 QEM announced:

2025 Annual Report...the next 12 months will see QEM continue evaluation of our flagship Julia Creek Vanadium and Energy Project, with priority on flowsheet options, progressing the EIS and continuing our renewable energy initiatives with Potentia Energy.

Tivan Limited [ASX:TVN] (formerly TNG Ltd [ASX:TNG](OTCPK:TNGZF)

Tivan 100% owns Speewah Mining Pty Ltd, the owner of the Speewah Vanadium-Titanium-Iron Project and the Speewah Fluorite Project in WA. They also own the high grade Sandover Fluorite Project in Northern Territory.

On October 23 Tivan announced:

Quarterly Activities Report...Speewah Vanadium Project (WA; Tivan 100%)...Tivan is focused on evaluating the preferred technology pathway for the project for the production of vanadium products - between the TIVAN+ minerals processing technology with CSIRO and a conventional salt roast processing operation. The project is also planned to comprise a separate vanadium electrolyte production facility proposed to be located at the Middle Arm Sustainable Development Precinct in Darwin... Evaluation of the preferred technology pathway continued during the quarter, with Tivan mindful of the potential of increased policy support for the vanadium sector from the Australian government.

Neometals [ASX:NMT] (OTCQX:NMTAY)(OTCPK:RDRUY) (OTCPK:RRSSF)

Neometals 100% own the Barrambie Titanium Vanadium Iron Project in Western Australia, but are looking at divesting the Barrambie VTM Deposit, but keeping the Barrambie Gold Project. They also own 86.1% of the Vanadium Recovery Project JV.

On October 28 Neometals announced:

Quarterly Activities Report For the quarter ended 30 September 2025...

  • Discussions continued in relation to the divestment of the Barrambie titanium and vanadium deposit...
  • Vanadium Recovery – Pori Vanadium Project (86.1% NMT, via Recycling Industries Scandinavia AB (“RISAB”)) Equity and debt funding process continued with a number of parties in the project data room...
  • Cash balance of A$10.2M.

Graphite miners with potential vanadium projects

  • Syrah Resources [ASX:SYR] (OTCPK:SYAAF) (OTC:SRHYY)
  • NextSource Materials [TSX:NEXT]
  • DNI Metals [TSXV:DNI] [GR:DG7N](OTC:DMNKF)

Other listed vanadium juniors

  • BlackRock Metals (Private)
  • Blue Sky Uranium [TSXV:BSK] (OTCQB:BKUCF)
  • Critical Minerals Group [ASX:CMG]
  • Currie Rose Resources Inc. [TSXV:CUI]
  • Gladiator Resources [ASX:GLA]
  • Golcap Resources Corp. [CSE:GCP]
  • Golden Deeps [ASX:GED]
  • Intermin Resources [ASX:IRC]
  • Manuka Resources [ASX:MKR]
  • Maxtech Ventures [CSE:MVT]
  • Moab Minerals [ASX:MOM]
  • New Energy Minerals [ASX: NXE]

  • Surefire Resources [ASX:SRN]
  • Trigon Metals Inc. [TSXV:TM] (OTC:PNTZF)
  • UVRE [ASX:UVA]
  • Venus Metals [ASX:VMC]
  • Victory Metals [TSXV:VMX]
  • Viking Mines [ASX:VKA]

VRFB Companies

  • Protean Energy [ASX:POW] [GR:SHE1]
  • Enerox GmbH (90% Bushveld/10% Cellcube Energy Storage Systems)
  • Invinity Energy Systems (LSE:IES) (IVVGF) (OTCQX:IESVF)

Conclusion

October saw China spot vanadium pentoxide prices and ferrovanadium prices flat for the past month. Prices remain at very low levels.

Highlights for the month include:

  • U.S. and Australia sign critical minerals agreement with $8.5 billion project pipeline.
  • The US-AU Critical Minerals Framework is expected to begin investing in about a dozen projects necessary for producing weapons, electronics and renewables.
  • VRFBs are not new, but they are now entering a more serious growth phase. Installed capacity is expected to rise ten-fold by 2030, moving from 4 GWh today to around 40 GWh, with potential annual deployments of up to 50 GWh.
  • Glencore - Community unrest erupts at Glencore’s Rhovan vanadium mine after expiry of solar project contracts.
  • Largo receives executed Binding Term Sheet from lenders representing US$84.2M. Raises US$23.4M in equity offers.
  • Energy Fuels announces closing of upsized US$700.0M Convertible Senior Notes offering.
  • Ferro-Alloy Resources - H1, 2025 loss of US$3.5M. Positive FS results on Phase 1 of the large Balasausqandiq Vanadium Project for 8,500tpa V2O5 production (post tax NPV8% of US$748m IRR of 22%), with funding required to enter production of US$520m. Cash cost of US$0.36/lb (net of by-product credits).

  • Western Uranium & Vanadium Corp. announces closing of Mineral Lode claims acquisition.

  • Australian Vanadium proposes a 25:1 share consolidation.

As usual all comments are welcome.

data.title: Stellantis: A Potential Value Trap Rather Than An Undervalued Opportunity
data.description:
Once again, Stellantis (STLA) surprises us. As some might remember, I invested in the stock between 2020 and 2024. At first, I thought the stock was deeply undervalued, and I indeed saw my gains double. But I was slow to realize how Stellantis' success hinged on supply chain bottlenecks. Once these were eased, the company wasn't able to accept a volume over value strategy and kept focusing on margins. The result was a bloodbath, especially in the U.S., where GM's strategy proved more resilient amid different market conditions and is now paying off as General Motors is not offering big discounts as most of its peers because it has well-positioned its models in the right price tiers.

In the end, I exited the stock more or less flat, with only the hefty dividends received as the true gains (a 25% yield, more or less). This taught me a lesson: the investment in Stellantis was reasonable, but it had to be timed better. This made me understand that Stellantis wasn't the best fit for my portfolio, since I try to hold predictable companies. I thus reinvested the capital into better plays, such as Prysmian (OTCPK:PRYMF) and Ferrari (RACE).

Now, last week we saw both GM and Ford (F) reporting strong results; the market reacted and sent both stocks up double-digits. We heard about recovering industry volumes and indeed some expectations about Stellantis mounted as we waited for the company to publish its sales release (Stellantis is headquartered in the Netherlands and, therefore, issues its results semiannually, reporting only its sales in Q1 and Q3 of each fiscal year). But as soon as Stellantis reported its Q3 sales, the stock slumped and went down 9%. What is going on?

First of all, Stellantis reported a 13% YoY increase both in shipments (1.3M) and revenues (EUR 37.2B). This ends the brutal streak of 7 consecutive quarters of sequential declines. Moreover, Stellantis reported that its market share in the U.S. grew by around 40 bps, which is another positive signal. A couple of years ago, Stellantis held a market share above 10%. Right now, it is down to 7.4%. Since North America is Stellantis' most profitable market, it is undoubtedly good news that the company was finally able to gain a bit of market share. This happened thanks to the strong sales of the new Jeep and Ram models, with Q4 expected to perform even better.

When we look at the net revenues and shipments breakdown by region, we see that North America's deliveries increased by 35% to 403k units, and net revenues were up 29% to EUR 16B. Europe saw its shipments increase by 8% to 534k units, with revenues increasing 4% to EUR 13B. South America, which has historically been a very successful end market for Stellantis, reported a 3% decline in shipments to 252k units, with revenues down even more (-5%) to EUR 4 B. However, the Middle East and Africa continued performing well, with shipments up 21% YoY to 94k and net revenues up by 9% to EUR 2.1B.

However, in the sales call, the new CEO, Antonio Filosa, explained that Europe didn't perform as well as expected, with a market share loss of 70 bps. In fact, the French and Italian markets were softer than previously anticipated, and the LCV business also lost some traction. As a reminder, LCVs represent Stellantis' most profitable segment and generate around a third of total revenues.

So, the question remains. Why did Stellantis lose a tenth of its market cap after this sales release?

Well, the main reason comes from a contextual announcement that Stellantis made, stating that it has committed to its largest single investment program ever, which will make it deploy $13B in the U.S. over the next 4 years. By doing so, Stellantis aims to produce around 50% of its U.S. sales directly in the U.S.

Why is this so concerning? Well, first and foremost, until two years ago, Stellantis was swimming in cash and had around EUR 45B parked in cash, making it one of the few automakers with a positive net cash position, even when including financial debt. The last year of Carlos Tavares' tenure brought along the surprise no one expected. A month or so after having reassured investors that the company would be fine in 2024, Stellantis released a profit warning and said it would end the year burning around EUR 10B in cash. This is why we now see that Stellantis' cash balance was EUR 32.4B at the end of 2024 and is now around EUR 29B. During the sales release, Stellantis only said that in the second half, it will improve its FCF generation versus the first half of the year, which ended with EUR -3B. So, I think what Stellantis meant by saying it will improve its result is that it won't be FCF positive, but that it will lose less. Let's say it will burn EUR 1.5B. We have a cash position that could be sitting at EUR 27B. When we subtract the large investment that was announced, we see that each year, Stellantis will use at least EUR 3.25B. Moreover, when such a large industrial plan is announced, we can expect that the largest part of this capital will be deployed in the early stages, thus severely impacting the next two fiscal years. In the meantime, Stellantis has become a net debt-positive company, thus eliminating one of the reasons why many of us considered it a steal just a few years ago. Now, although the company is back to a share price below $10, its fundamentals have changed. Right now, Stellantis is burning cash. Secondly, it has lost meaningful market share in its most profitable market. Third, its margins have come down from 12% to 4%-5%. Of course, the stock is being re-rated.

While from a top-line revival perspective, this sales report could be considered encouraging, cash flow generation is still to be recovered. Therefore, the investment thesis can solely rely right now on considering Stellantis a turnaround play and not a fundamentally undervalued company. After all, the plunge in earnings will likely make Stellantis report negative EPS this year, which means that the PE ratio doesn't make sense anymore. Right now, the fwd PE sits at 24.2, but it must be taken with a grain of salt. I would rather use the EV/EBITDA ratio: the TTM is 16.8, while the fwd is 3.7. This is a big difference and it shows how compressed Stellantis' EBITDA has been in the past 4 quarters. At the same time, many believe it will come back to more normal levels of around ERU 10B. We will have to wait one more quarter before we see some financial numbers, but we should not be so unrealistic as to expect the company to be back to EUR 20B in EBITDA soon. Considering that its cash position will decrease, we will have an EV that goes up, meaning that the ratio could expand as a result of the change in the capital structure of the company.

No matter how I twist it, and as much as I don't like what I am saying since I wish Stellantis would achieve success, I don't see any room to step back in the stock. As a turnaround play, the tide is still highly uncertain, and the stock resembles more of a value trap rather than an undervalued opportunity. Right now, among the Detroit Big Three, I continue saying that my preference goes to GM. As for Stellantis, I confirm my sell rating.

data.title: Bullish Dollar Consolidation
data.description:
Overview

After extending this week's rally yesterday, the US dollar (DXY) is consolidating yesterday's gains in what appears to be favorable price action. The pullback from greenback's best level has been shallow. The US struck several trade deals this week and secured a trade truce with China, even if many are skeptical of its longevity, and the Federal Reserve pushed against a December cut, and the futures market has reduced the odds to about 2/3rd from near certainty. Emerging market currencies are mixed, but this week's highlights include the PBOC setting the dollar's fix at a new low since October on Wednesday before steadying it in the last two sessions, and the (3.6%) recovery of the Argentine peso following last Sunday's election.

The Nikkei (NKY:IND) extended its weekly advance today. The 2.1% gain today brings the weekly rise to 6.3%. Most of the other large equity markets in the region but South Korea's Kospi (KOSPI) weakened today. Yet, the MSCI Asia Pacific index is closing higher on the week and is securing its seventh consecutive monthly advance. Europe's STOXX 600 (STOXX) is weaker for the fourth consecutive session, which matches its longest decline since June. Still, it is poised to settle higher for the fourth consecutive month. Helped by Amazon (AMZN) and Apple (AAPL), US index futures are trading higher today. The S&P 500 (SPX) and Nasdaq (NDX) will settle higher for the sixth and seventh consecutive months, respectively. European and US 10-year benchmark yields are slightly firmer today. Near 4.10%, the 10-year US Treasury yield (US10Y) is up around 12 bp this week, the most among the G10 countries. Gold is trading heavier, and barring a significant recovery, will settle lower in back-to-back weeks for the first time since July. December WTI is hovering near $60 and is off about 2% this week.

USD: A combination of the hawkish cut by the Fed and what appears to be an important de-escalation of US-China trade tensions (with some hope it can last a year) helped lift the Dollar Index to a new high for the month, near 99.70. Since the high was recorded in early North American turnover yesterday, DXY has remained above 99.40. Today's consolidation, near yesterday's high, looks constructive, and the next target is the 100.00-100.25 area. October is the second month of the year that DXY has risen and, more broadly, the dollar appreciated against all the G10 currencies. The Dollar Index has risen by around 2% this month despite lower yields, the government shutdown and the anticipation and delivery of the Federal Reserve's second rate cut of the year. The greenback's gains seemed to be a function of market positioning, optimism that the elevated Washington-Beijing tensions were part positioning ahead of new negotiations, and poor developments in Europe and Japan. While the House of Representatives remains out of session, the Senate has symbolically moved this week to check tariffs on Brazil, to end the "emergency" that has been used to justify many tariffs and to make SNAP contingency funds available. Yet, without the House's approval, these are symbolic measures but show dissent among some Republican senators.

Euro: The euro held above $1.1600 in the European morning yesterday, but the entry of North American players saw it sold to about $1.1545, a few hundredths of a cent above the month's low. It is holding today, but the single currency has barely traded above previous support near $1.1575. A break of the $1.1540 area leaves little on the charts ahead of the late July/early August lows near $1.1400. A move back above $1.16 would help stabilize the technical tone. The US two-year premium over Germany is around 162 bp, the highest since early September. The ECB's decision to stand pat yesterday and comments from President Lagarde suggesting the bar to another cut is high takes the thunder away from today's preliminary October CPI. It rose 0.2% in the month, but due to the base effect, the year-over-year rate slipped to 2.1% from 2.2%. The core rate was steady at 2.4%.

CNY: The dollar rose by about 0.25% against the offshore yuan yesterday, its largest single-day advance this month. It reached almost CNH7.1180, and this is holding today. The halfway mark of this year's range is around CNH7.1210. Above there, resistance is seen in the CNH7.1280-7.1300 area. Apparently, the foreign exchange market was not a subject of US-China negotiations. The PBOC set the dollar's fix at CNY7.0880 (CNY7.0864 yesterday and CNY7.0928 a week ago). It is the first back-to-back increase in the dollar's reference rate this month. China's October PMI softened. The manufacturing PMI eased to 49.0 from 49.8. It has been below the 50 boom/bust mark since April. The non-manufacturing PMI has held up better. Although it has not been below 50 this year, it has not been above 50.5 since May. It ticked up to 50.1 from 50.0, the low for the year. The composite eased to 50.0, which is the lowest it has been since the end of 2022 (50.6 in September). It averaged 50.4 in Q2 and Q3.

JPY: The backing up of US interest rates, despite or because of the Fed's cut Wednesday, and the BOJ's seeming lack of urgency to raise rates yesterday weighed on the yen. The dollar, which finished last week near JPY152.85, rose to nearly JPY154.45 yesterday, which is the lower end of a resistance band that extends to JPY155. Its consolidation today (between ~JPY153.65 and JPY154.40) looks bullish. The dollar's low for the year was recorded in April a little below JPY140. The high for the year was seen in January, almost JPY159. Today's data may help inform the BOJ's next rate decision. The economy recovered in September from a weak August, and core Tokyo CPI likely signals the direction of the national reading due in a few weeks. The headline and core measures rose from 2.5% to 2.8%. The September jobless rate was steady at 2.6%, while retail sales rose 0.3% after a revised 0.9% decline in August (initially -1.1%) and industrial output rose 2.2% (-1.5% in August). The swaps market has about a 46% chance of a hike in December, down slightly from the end of last week. On the contrary, we suspect the odds have crept up.

GBP: Sterling has had a tough week, though the economic diary was light. It was sold to a six-month low yesterday, slightly above $1.3115. Although it stabilized and recovered back above the $1.3140 area that held in May and August, the technical tone has deteriorated, and it remains below the 200-day moving average (~$1.3245) for the first time since April. It has held above yesterday's lows today but has been unable to rise above the $1.3165 area. A weekly close below $1.3140 would leave it in a vulnerable position. The main feature next week is the central bank meeting. The swaps market has around 25% chance of a cut. It was less than 10% at the end of last month. One large US investment bank forecasts a BOE cut and is one of the two of 16 economists surveyed by Bloomberg that anticipate a cut.

CAD: After the Bank of Canada cut rates on Wednesday, the US dollar extended its pullback against the Canadian dollar, falling to its lowest level in more than a month, slightly below CAD1.3890. The greenback's surge after the hawkish cut by the Fed lifted it back to around CAD1.3950, and the follow-through action yesterday saw it near CAD1.4015. This met the (61.8%) retracement of the US dollar's retreat from the six-month high recorded on October 14 near CAD1.4080. It is trading quietly (~CAD1.3980-1.4010) but firmly in the upper end of yesterday's range. StatCan is expected to shortly report that the economy stagnated in August after growing 0.2% in July. The monthly GDP has not risen for two consecutive months since September-October 2024. The Bank of Canada delivered its fourth rate cut of the year on Wednesday, and the official comments confirm what the market already suspected: the bar to another cut is high.

AUD: The Australian dollar rallied from around $0.6445 on October 17 to about $0.6615 before the Federal Reserve's rate cut on October 29. Yesterday, it was sold to almost $0.6530 to meet the (50%) retracement of the rally. While yesterday's low is holding, the Aussie has barely traded to $0.6560. A break of $0.6530 can spur a move toward $0.6500. The elevated CPI reading on Wednesday is understood as practically ruling out a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia next week. Today's Q3 PPI does not change that calculus. It rose 1.0% (0.7% in Q2), and the year-over-year rate edged up to 3.5% (from 3.4% in Q2).

MXN: The dollar broke out of the narrow consolidative range to the upside and briefly traded above MXN18.60 yesterday for the first time in two and a half weeks. The high for the month set on October 10 was a little below MXN18.64, while the high from October 14 was slightly below MXN18.63. The dollar is holding above MXN18.50 today. It has not spent an entire session above there since September 10. The 0.3% contraction in Q3 GDP that Mexico reported yesterday reinforces speculation that Banxico will cut rates next week to 7.25% from 7.50%. It will be the seventh rate cut this year for a cumulative reduction of 275 bp. In 2024, the central bank cut 125 bp. Brazil's central bank also meets next week. It is expected to keep the Selic rate at 15.00%, where it has been since June. The US dollar recovered from BRL5.3345 on Wednesday and approached the week's high and the 20-day moving average near BRL5.3950 yesterday. The next area of resistance is around BRL5.4050-5.4300. Coming into today, the US dollar has fallen by about 3.5% against the Argentine peso since this week, since Milei's party did better than expected in the election. The 10-year dollar bond yield has fallen by almost 25 bp this week. Although the US Treasury has declared victory, for many market participants the jury is still out.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: DocuSign: Not Worth Picking Up Yet
data.description:
DocuSign, Inc. (DOCU) experienced a major boom during the pandemic, unsurprisingly. However, as the world returned to normalcy, the stock has essentially erased all those gains. Early this year, I initiated the stock at a sell rating, citing weak fundamentals and overvaluation. Since that article, DocuSign has plunged ~23%, so my bearish view has played out. The company reported earnings back in September but won't report again until December, and I believe this is a good time to take another look at their results.

In the below analysis, few signs of a turnaround are found. Top line growth remains sluggish, and billings guidance was uninspiring. Profitability also seems to be under pressure as both gross and operating margins contract, so despite the introduction of AI tools into their solutions, not much is going right for the company at this point. That said, the forward P/E ratio has contracted to a justified level, so I have decided to upgrade DocuSign to a hold rating on the basis of valuation.

Too Many Customers?

Is it possible to have too many users or customers? While it's great that DocuSign has a strong user base, it also raises the question of whether there is still room to grow. As you can see in the company overview above, they are already the number one e-signature solution, and more importantly, 95% of the Fortune 500 are already customers. It's good news that they have been able to attract so many clients, but at the same time, where do they go from here? They're in 180 countries already and have over a billion users, and so while they hold a leadership position in their space, I believe investors should consider that a good part of the potential market has now been accounted for.

Innovation To Drive Growth

It does seem that management is also seeing the growth challenges ahead, so they are focusing on innovation in order to drive future growth. Above is a timeline of the company's evolution, and as you can see, from 2024 onwards, they have transitioned into an era of "Intelligent Agreement Management." They have added new solutions to their portfolio and have adopted AI to create tools like AI-assisted review and AI extractions. Through the creation of these new tools, DocuSign will be able to offer more services to customers, and that in turn should help them to drive top-line growth. Now let's jump into their financials to look for signs of re-acceleration.

Top-Line Growth Remains Subdued

For FY2026 Q2, DocuSign reported revenues of $800.6 million, representing a 9% increase YoY. While that is still a satisfactory growth rate, as you can see above, revenue growth has been very sluggish since late calendar 2023. There is some rebound in growth from the previous quarter, but overall, it may be too early to conclude that an inflection point is in. Still, they were able to beat analysts' expectations by $20.05 million, so results are better than feared. Looking at their subscription revenues specifically, there has also been recent sluggishness with growth at just 9% as well. Therefore, there hasn't been enough acceleration to show that growth is truly headed in the right direction. Their billings do show some better signs, however.

While revenues aren't showing many signs of improving business activity, the company's billings show that the worst may be over. As you can see above, for Q2 they reported billings of $818 million, representing a 13% YoY increase. That is the highest growth rate we have seen in the past five quarters by some distance. Also note that the rolling four-quarter YoY growth rate has ticked up notably to 9%. Therefore, moving forward, revenue growth may have the potential to pick up, as there are some early signs of better demand in these billing figures.

Margins Headed In Wrong Direction

In addition to some top line worries, the company's margins also seem to be under some pressure. For gross margin there was notable contraction, especially for their core subscription business. For subscriptions, gross margin contracted by 40 basis points, while the company as a whole saw a contraction of 20 basis points. This could indicate that cost control hasn't been great, but it also may show that clients aren't opting for their higher-margin products. That client behavior could be a concern moving forward. The bad news doesn't stop there, however.

Adjusted operating margin contracted by a rather worrying 240 basis points YoY to 29.8%, and increases in operating expenses are to blame. While I see no problem with the increase in R&D spending as a percentage of revenues, the increases in sales & marketing and general & administrative expenses are clearly undesirable. S&M expenses as a percentage of revenues increased by 80 basis points YoY, while G&A expenses increased 90 basis points to 7.9% of revenues. These are clear signs that corporate efficiency has not been favorable.

As a result of contracting margins, DocuSign reported an adjusted EPS of $0.92, representing a decline of 5.15% YoY. A bottom-line decline is, of course, not a great sign. Still, they managed to beat analyst estimates by $0.07, so expectations were very low to begin with. Currently, it seems that DocuSign is dealing with problems on two fronts. Top line growth remains sluggish, and profitability is also not headed in the right direction.

Guidance Raised

Despite what I would call lackluster Q2 results, DocuSign was still able to deliver a beat and raise. All of the above FY2026 guidance figures have been updated favorably, and that is, of course, welcome news for investors. The company is now expecting revenue growth to be at about 7%. That is a slowdown from FY2025's 8% increase, and so again, the top line isn't showing signs of a re-acceleration.

For subscription revenues in particular, the projected 8% increase would be unchanged from FY2025, so at least for their core business, things are shaping up to be steady. That's also the case for billings. Their 7% growth projection would also be unchanged from the previous year. However, recall that Billings growth was 13% in Q2. Therefore, the acceleration we saw may not continue for FY2026 as a whole, and that makes the demand outlook shaky once again.

As for their margins, the above ranges for both gross margin and operating margin are below what we saw in FY2025, so the efficiency and profitability woes we discussed above are also happening in the annual timeframe. Overall, while a raising of guidance is surely welcomed, I believe these updated figures still don't provide much promise that the company has hit an inflection point.

Valuation Likely Fair

During this year, DocuSign's forward P/E ratio has continued to trend down. At a current reading of 18.76, the multiple is essentially at one year lows. I believe the valuation correctly reflects the fundamentals right now. Today, we have learned quite a bit about the company. Revenues remain sluggish, and while Q2 billings were quite strong, full year guidance for billings shows that demand remains subdued. Profitability is also under pressure, and if they don't improve their corporate efficiency, the bottom line will pay the price. As stated just above, guidance was raised, but the new figures still don't show that a meaningful turnaround is happening. With that being the case, I find the valuation contraction this year to be unsurprising and justified. Currently, Seeking Alpha shows that DocuSign trades at around a 25% discount to the IT sector according to the non-GAAP forward P/E ratio. Given the struggles the company finds itself in, I would say that this valuation gap is an appropriate reflection of reality.

Conclusion

DocuSign has been under pressure ever since the pandemic was over, and from today's analysis, it seems the company will continue to experience sluggishness moving forward. As stated above, demand doesn't seem to be overly robust right now despite their expanded solutions portfolio. Furthermore, margin contraction is dragging down their profitability. While normally a beat and raise is a great sign, the updated guidance is still rather lackluster in my view. That said, the forward P/E ratio has come down quite a bit from earlier this year, and since the valuation is now justified, I have decided to upgrade to a neutral rating of hold.

data.title: Why Bausch Health Is A Buy After Rising 10% On Third-Quarter Results
data.description:
When Bausch Health Companies (BHC) posted third-quarter results, shares jumped to as high as almost $7.00 on the day. It ended up by 12.03% on October 30, up by 12.03%.

BHC has not seen a rally that big since August 12, when shares jumped by nearly 20%. Back then, it rose for the same reason: quarterly results.

Third-Quarter Results Recap

BHC reported GAAP earnings per share of $0.48, beating estimates by $0.10. Revenue topped $2.68 billion, up by 6.8% Y/Y. Chief Executive Officer Thomas Appio said that the firm achieved its tenth straight quarter of year-on-year revenue growth. Its DURECT acquisition was completed in the quarter, which strengthened its research and development growth platform. In addition, that complements BHC’s hepatology pipeline. It also increases revenue diversification, achieved through a wider reach by geography and by therapeutic areas.

The firm posted strong momentum across its platform. Both revenue and adjusted EBITDA increased by 7%, as shown below.

Cabtreo and Ryaltris revenue grew by 218% and 111%, respectively. BHC launched Cabtreo, a product from its dermatology business, in January 2024. This became the number one prescribed topical branded acne product in new patient starts. The CEO said that Cabtreo had 105,000 new patient prescriptions YTD, up 69% Y/Y.

Above: Dermatology grew at the fastest pace among the businesses in the diversified segment.

Xifaxan volume growth continued in Q3 to lift the Salix Segment. Xifaxan benefited from direct-to-consumer investments. This led to continued, new patient activations. NBRx (new-to-brand prescription) grew by 14%. However, Relistor and Trulance revenue and prescriptions fell.

Geographically, the emerging market (“EMEA”) grew by 12%, while Canada and Latin America (“LATAM”) fell by 8% and 17%, respectively:

In Canada, BHC’s LOE portfolio hurt the 21% growth performance of its promoted portfolio. Watch for the licensing clearance for Thermage in Canada, now at the fourth generation of radio frequency technology, to help its performance in the country. Thermage is a nonsurgical treatment technology used to provide skin tightening and smoothing treatments globally. In South Korea, Thermage surpassed the 1,000 unit installed base milestone.

Solta is poised to grow from here. BHC launched Fraxel FTX in April. The leading skin rejuvenation treatment, performed by dermatologists, plastic surgeons, and other licensed aesthetics professionals in the U.S., is in the early phases. BHC reported double-digit percentage revenue growth in all three regions. It highlighted the 96% growth in South Korea.

Opportunities From BHC Stock

BHC remains committed to unlocking value for its stakeholders. The firm closed a $7.9 billion refinancing transaction earlier this year. This is the early step in unlocking both BHC and the B+L assets. In Q3, B+L revenue grew by 7%:

Xifaxan pricing grew in the modest mid-single-digit percentage. Volume is growing at a balanced pace across all channels. BHC used an AI-powered engine to optimize its call points. That should lead to higher script growth.

Guidance

BHC raised its guidance slightly on adjusted EBITDA and adjusted operating cash flow. The OCF increased to up to $1.025 billion. This is likely due to a good portion of adjustments in gross-to-net rebates related to its inventory in the channel.

BHC likely raised its adjusted EBITDA by managing its SG&A spending. Q3 costs were unusually low after the firm changed its accruals for nonrecurring items. Investors should look out for the firm lowering expenses by increasing marketing and operating efficiencies. That might lead to an increase in next year’s guidance.

Growth Catalysts

Xifaxan is the first of BHC’s growth catalysts. The firm must continue its investments to support Xifaxan and Cabtreo growth. The aesthetics business is the second growth catalyst for its global revenue. BHC is making long-term investments in research and development to support the innovation pipeline. Thermage FCX in Canada and Fraxel FTX in the U.S. are the products that come to mind.

Innovation in hepatology is BHC’s third growth catalyst. Larsucosterol, from its DURECT acquisition, is undergoing a study for treating alcohol-associated hepatitis. It will start the phase 3 trial by early 2026.

In this segment, the RED-C program faces no competition. The market does not have an approved product for the primary prevention of overt hepatic encephalopathy (“OHE”). The market opportunity is 1.9 million patients in the U.S. BHC has two global Phase 3 studies that it expects will have a readout in early 2026.

Stock Grades

BHC’s momentum grade fell after shares peaked at above $8 in the summer to trade below $6.00 recently. The D+ grade might rise back to a C if its recent rally to $6.61 holds.

BHC’s valuation is strong, with an ‘A’ grade. In the breakdown, the lowest grade is a B:

Your Takeaway

BHC stock is a stock for speculative value investors to consider. I rate Bausch a buy. Shares have lost 5.57% since I last covered the company, compared to a 5.84% gain in the S&P 500. B+L (BLCO) is also a compelling stock to hold. Seeking Alpha scored BLCO stock a buy with a 3.54/5.00 rating. In comparison, BHC stock has a ‘Hold’ rating on a 2.87/5.00 rating.

data.title: Gold Demand Trends: Q3 2025
data.description:
Gold sets new records in Q3

Demand rises to a new high in tandem with the price

Total gold demand, including OTC, grew 3% y/y to 1,313t, the highest quarterly total in our data series. Yet this was eclipsed by the value measure of demand, which jumped 44% y/y to a record of US$146bn in Q3.

Year-to-date demand is 1% higher at 3,717t, equating to US$384bn in value, up 41% y/y.

Investors remained firmly in the driving seat in Q3. Huge ETF buying (+222t), accompanied by a fourth successive quarter of bar and coin demand above 300t (316t) fuelled the rise in overall demand.

Central bank buying remained elevated at 220t, 28% up on the prior quarter, albeit that y-t-d buying of 634t has been at a slower pace than the 724t bought in the first three quarters of last year.

Jewellery consumption in Q3 posted a double-digit y/y decline (the sixth in succession) to 371t, as volumes remained under pressure in the record price environment. This contrasts with a 13% y/y increase in value to US$41bn.

Technology demand was fractionally weaker compared with Q3’24. Support from growing AI demand met with headwinds from US tariff policy and the surging gold price.

Highlights

The LBMA (PM) gold price hit 13 new all-time highs in the quarter. The price rose 16% during Q3 and generated an average quarterly price of US$3456.54/oz, up 40% y/y and 5% q/q.

Total gold supply rose 3% y/y to a quarterly record of 1,313t.Mine production, which typically sees seasonal growth in Q3, was up 2% y/y to 977t.

The supply of recycled gold remained elevated but stable at 344t: up 6% y/y, down 1% q/q. Recycling activity was restrained to some degree by expectations of further price gains and generally supportive economic conditions.

OTC investment added 55t to Q3 demand. This measure captures continued widespread global interest from institutions and high net worth individuals, particularly in September.

Chart 1: Investment demand continued to drive demand growth in Q3

Total quarterly demand by sector in tonnes and US$bn

Gold supply and demand

Table 1: Quarterly gold supply and demand by sector, tonnes

Outlook

Given the pace of investment and price rises, we revise our FY 2025 investment materially higher and our jewellery expectations lower. All other forecasts remain largely unchanged as we head into the final quarter.

  • Investment: The surprising pace of gold ETF accumulation has picked up more steam globally in Q4, to briefly break through prior peak holdings. We think it could continue supported by a solid case for further accumulation
  • Bar and coin buying has been stalwart this year despite the price rally. We maintain our previously positive targets but add a little further upside potential, given a positive outlook for China and India
  • Fabrication: High prices are likely to remain the biggest obstacle to jewellery demand volumes. Even if they soften in Q4, we think adjustment to such prices will take time to materialise. Our ‘no growth’ technology estimate remains in place, torn between thrifting and AI investment.
  • Central banks: We revise our central bank expectations modestly higher, encouraged by demand resilience in Q3 in the face of rapid price rises. A broadening of demand is another welcome and supportive factor.
  • Supply: Ramp ups and high margins continue to incentivise mine production. But outages and revisions might once again disappoint those expecting an annual record. Hedging is expected to be muted.
  • Recycling continues to surprise in its lacklustre response. Expectations of yet higher prices, lack of economic distress, lack of ready supplies and a preference to use gold for collateralisation are likely culprits. But risks of a surge are not to be discounted in the price environment.

Expected change in annual gold demand and supply

Investment

The fate of the US dollar remains key for investment decisions, under headlines such as ‘debasement’ and ‘de-dollarisation’. There is some disagreement about how readily these apply; our view is that the reality is more subtle.1 A weaker dollar during the first nine months of 2025 is largely pinned on hedging activity. US assets may have lost some of their exceptionalism but they remain core to most global portfolios. Hedging will just put the onus on them working a little harder for investors, and a marginal shift into less crowded assets is prudent portfolio management.

Anticipated US policy rate cuts is another key pillar for investors. While the opportunity cost motive remains important, the potential consequences of lower rates add more nuance, potentially reflecting a worsening US economy but also stoking fears of inflation; the by-now familiar theme of stagflation, historically supportive of gold.

Gold ETF demand was the standout sector y-t-d. We think the drivers of this demand remain intact even after tonnage holdings eclipsed their 2020 highs. As a share of general portfolios, gold remains under-allocated and a flood of new investors could easily push holdings through the previous peak given the strategic case to do so remains solid.

But there are tactical risks that could derail further inflows. These include: technical sell signals; a continued easing of tariff tensions; geopolitical resolutions; softening fears of US Fed independence; and a rotation out of gold into ‘cheaper’ assets. Such risks naturally proliferate when prices move this fast and holdings approach previous peaks.

Some further profit-taking in Q4 would not come as a surprise following the mid-October sell-off, although the selling appears to have been focused outside of the gold ETF market, possibly driven by Commodity Trading Advisor (CTA) activity.2 We remain optimistic on North American and European demand and view the economic and political backdrop as constructive for resumed buying of any dips. Our forecast is raised and our confidence bands narrowed.

With the FOMO bar and coin trade in full swing – helped along by geopolitical concerns – we maintain our positive full-year estimate. Gold’s rapid price rise has not been a deterrent as it has been on occasion historically. On the contrary, retail activity chasing rising prices should be a boon for the sector, particularly following short-term corrections. This applies broadly across geographies, with China and India seen picking up steam in Q4. Trade tensions and economic pessimism will likely drive Chinese buying, while Indian investors may eschew jewellery in favour of lower margin bar and coin. Anecdotally, softer US bar and coin demand appears to have sharply reversed at the start of Q4.

Fabrication

A glum start to Q3’25 was on the cards for jewellery demand. Although China’s demand in tonnes echoed the lows of the Global Financial Crisis, a q/q pickup and strong spending provided some welcome relief. Any price softness in Q4 will indicate how quickly and confidently consumers adjust to prices. Given how prolonged the slump has been and how strongly prices have risen, the recovery might not be rapid.

Indian volume demand was also weak but did not plumb crisis-level depths. A likely resilient economy ahead should also give us useful statistics on price adjustment in Q4, absent a sharp move higher or lower in prices.

Other regions mirrored consumption patterns in the two largest purchasing centres, one reason models of global demand tend to be quite straightforward to construct. Jewellery responds quite consistently across geographies to price, lagged price adjustments and changes in income. Given no major expected changes in income on a global level in Q4 (albeit that broad income growth remains supportive longer-term), price movements and consumer adjustment are likely to dictate the sectors final quarter tally.

There is little to be added to what we have said previously about technology demand. Price pressure is a constant feature for an industry accustomed to thrifting. But at the same time it continues to benefit from the AI boom. This tug of war will likely flatten demand for the year.

Central banks

Central banks are likely to continue their buying spree. Our full year estimate of between 750-900t – barring any surprises - is lower than last year, but remains – in line with y-t-d flows – surprisingly resilient given strong price rises. Upside and downside risks are balanced, dictated largely by price volatility. However, three factors make us positive on continued demand in Q4 and beyond:

  • Major EM countries’ FX reserves growth (y/y) is forecast to pick up in Q4
  • Demand has broadened, with hitherto dormant banks becoming active
  • Our 2025 central bank survey showed the strongest intention to continue buying since it was initiated in 2019.

Supply

The theme of production growth from ramp-ups and new projects led by Ghana, Canada and Australia could take production to a new record in FY2025. However, suspension of a few operations makes the prediction a little less certain.

Strong prices will likely continue to incentivise hedging contracts to expire naturally, and this is likely to remain a negligible feature of total mine supply. But while prices are materially higher than the last quarter, the themes remain unchanged. A more significant price drop, unlikely in our view, could encourage some producers to lock in prices. Although, looking back at the largest drawdowns during recent rallies, our data shows no discernible aggregate rise in hedging (Q4 2008: -49t, Q4 2016: -24t and Q4 2023:+21t )

Recycling continues to undershoot expectations. Distress-selling will likely require a large dent in consumer balance sheets which we have not seen. The selling back we have seen appears opportunistic, and this if often a feature of a healthy rally in its early innings.

Recycling is likely to be muted unless store closures escalate, but there is scant evidence of that from China. We do note caution in India, where a material drop in gold prices could induce forced selling to cover loans collateralised with gold jewellery. All in all, a relatively healthy global economy, alongside widespread expectations of higher prices from analysts are likely reticence of people to sell back.3

Jewellery

Gold jewellery volumes plunge, while values soar

  • Surging, record-high gold prices in Q3 resulted in a sharp y/y drop in gold jewellery consumption
  • Global demand fell to its weakest for a third quarter since the Covid-hit low of 2020
  • Value measures of demand, in contrast, were almost universally higher, as consumers spent more on jewellery.
